messages.messageBody:
Oh my goodness, I am such a ninny. I thought you were
all talking about Internet Service Providers all this
time. Was I confused, or what?
Juli

--- Erica W <wallsfamily4@...> wrote:
> ISP Is Independent Study Program.

=====
You cannot teach a man anything; you can only help him to find it within himself --Galileo

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] ISP?
messages.msgSnippet: ISP Is Independent Study Program.  We are in Calif.  They have Puplic ISPs and private.  The private one I have found to use for next year alots alot of
messages.messageBody:
ISP Is Independent Study Program.  We are in Calif.  They have Puplic ISPs and private.  The private one I have found to use for next year alots alot of freedom.  The puplic one I was in for the last 3 years allowed some but each year they added more restrictions, rules ext....  The private ISP's vary with flexibility that I checked into.  ERica
----- Original Message -----
From: ambersand
To: Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, April 23, 2001 8:57 AM
Subject: [Unschooling-dotcom] ISP?

What's an ISP?  We have "Umbrella" schools here.  They are private school, as far as the state is concerned, but either offer homeschool programs or are exclusively homeschool.  In most, the family has to complete the schools program and submit the work or grades to the school for records.  Some even require meetings, testing at the school, and other stuff.  Homeschoolers in these umbrella schools are considered private school students by the state. 

ambersand

messages.subject: ISP?
messages.msgSnippet: What s an ISP?  We have Umbrella schools here.  They are private school, as far as the state is concerned, but either offer homeschool programs or are
messages.messageBody:
What's an ISP? We have "Umbrella" schools here. They are private school, as far as the state is concerned, but either offer homeschool programs or are exclusively homeschool. In most, the family has to complete the schools program and submit the work or grades to the school for records. Some even require meetings, testing at the school, and other stuff. Homeschoolers in these umbrella schools are considered private school students by the state.

ambersand
